message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory studies suggest intestinal obstruction, and among the options, only air in the bowel wall on abdominal X-ray is suggestive of this. Diffuse microcolon on barium enema is seen in Hirschsprung’s disease. No air in the rectum on abdominal X-ray suggests meconium ileus. An epigastric olive-shaped mass on abdominal sonography suggests infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and frank blood in the diaper suggests the most likely diagnosis is intussusception. Air in the bowel wall on abdominal x-ray is a classic sign of intussusception. Options A and B are findings seen in Hirschsprung disease. Option D describes the finding of pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Bilious vomiting, lethargy, and abdominal distension suggest a bowel obstruction. The presence of air in the bowel wall on abdominal X-ray is consistent with the diagnosis of necrotizing enterocolitis, which is a common cause of bowel obstruction in neonates. Diffuse microcolon on barium enema and no air in the rectum on abdominal X-ray are not consistent with this diagnosis. An epigastric olive-shaped mass on abdominal sonography may be suggestive of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis but is not related to bowel obstruction.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a possible intestinal obstruction, and the most likely finding on abdominal X-ray is air in the bowel wall. Option A is not likely in this scenario since the baby passed meconium on the 2nd day after birth. Option B is associated with Hirschsprung disease, but an olive-shaped mass would also be visible on X-ray. Option D is associated with pyloric stenosis, which is not likely to cause bilious vomiting.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings suggest a possible volvulus or malrotation, which can be diagnosed with an abdominal X-ray showing air in the bowel wall. Diffuse microcolon and an epigastric olive-shaped mass are associated with Hirschsprung disease and pyloric stenosis, respectively, which are less likely in this case. No air in the rectum suggests meconium ileus, which is also less likely given that meconium was passed on the 2nd day after birth.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and frank blood in diaper suggests neonatal intestinal obstruction. Air in the bowel wall on abdominal X-ray is the most likely finding in this situation. Diffuse microcolon on barium enema suggests Hirschsprung's disease, which does not present with bilious vomiting. No air in the rectum on abdominal X-ray suggests meconium ileus. An epigastric olive-shaped mass on abdominal sonography suggests pyloric stenosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest intestinal obstruction, and the most likely finding in this patient would be air in the bowel wall on abdominal X-ray. Diffuse microcolon on barium enema and no air in the rectum on abdominal X-ray are findings in Hirschsprung disease, which is not the most likely diagnosis in this case. An epigastric olive-shaped mass on abdominal sonography would suggest pyloric stenosis, which is not the most likely diagnosis in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Bilious vomiting in a neonate along with abdominal distension suggests intestinal obstruction. Air in bowel wall on abdominal X-ray is a common finding in malrotation with midgut volvulus. The other options are not specific to this presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of bilious vomiting, abdominal distension, and frank blood in the diaper suggest a gastrointestinal obstruction. Air in the bowel wall on abdominal X-ray suggests the possibility of necrotizing enterocolitis, a common cause of gastrointestinal obstruction in neonates. Diffuse microcolon on barium enema may suggest Hirschsprung's disease, which is less likely in this clinical scenario. No air in the rectum on abdominal X-ray may indicate anorectal malformation, which is less likely to cause frank blood in the diaper. An epigastric olive-shaped mass on abdominal sonography may indicate pyloric stenosis, which is less likely in this clinical scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Bilious vomiting and frank blood in the diaper are indicative of intestinal obstruction. The most likely finding on imaging is air in the bowel wall on abdominal X-ray, which suggests a possible perforation. Diffuse microcolon on barium enema is seen in meconium ileus. No air in rectum on abdominal X-ray suggests Hirschsprung disease, and an epigastric olive-shaped mass on abdominal sonography suggests pyloric stenosis.
